reviewText:
Fireplace simulator 2013 is more than just a sandbox game. The base storyline is in a world full of what seem to be orphans, the planet is getting colder, and to keep warm the ‚ÄúTomorrow Corporation‚Äù (Also the name of the developers) make an entertainment fireplace for all the boys and girls. The story continues as you play more into the game.


The base gameplay is clicking to create fire, and buying this from a catalogue to burn them. Unfortunately, you have to wait real time in order for the toys or electronics or whatever to arrive. This mechanic in the game is a massive downside, because some items in the later catalogues take a full 2 minutes. I see that the Dev‚Äôs wanted to make the game last longer but it's an annoying amount of time. Not long enough to alt tab and do something else, but long enough for the player to be annoyed. This time can be finished but using stamps, which can be collected by burning certain combos of objects. The list and what items required are online so this can be figured out easily. The gold coins you use to buy the objects to burn, are earned by, you guessed it, burning things. Its almost impossible to go broke in this game, with profiting from burning most things, and random spiders coming down and providing $ from their burnt corpses.


Burning combos, at first, seem to be the only objective. After a little bit of time someone in the next room sends you a letter, befriending you. Her and ‚ÄúThe weatherman‚Äù start to produce a legitimate storyline, making the game more appealing, drawing the player to play more. After grinding out the combos the player is handed a combo that is very easy to do, implying said player has a good memory. After that combo is completed a whole new world and story is added to the mix. The story is added in gradually but soon becomes the full focus. Its not only a well told story, but it's also a grasping one.


The graphics of the game fit the game alright, but the music in-game make the world around you feel so much darker and lonely, suiting the game perfectly.


Little inferno does some things right.


The sound and music is amazing

The story is one of the best i have ever seen out of an indie game

The combos, are witty and require some thinking, making it more immersive

The fireplace looks good, and get to annoying to look at

The objects you burn are rather comical

The ability to toss burning objects around your fireplace is good fun.


Little inferno does some things wrong too.

The lack of achievements and playing cards make the game a time killer, lowering their audience

The story although great, is slow to get started.

The repetitive nature could leave some players bored after an hour or two

The combos are both hard and easy at the same time, depending on the player‚Äôs skill

The combos are really easy to look up shortening the game time and lowering the fun


Little inferno, although a compelling story and a good time killer, isn't really worth the $10.99(CAD). With the lack of achievements and playing cards, it seems almost like a narrative interactive book, then a game. The price aside, i think people who love a great story, or even just wanting a few hours to go buy, should pick up this game. If it's ever on sale, get it. This is the weatherman, signing off. We‚Äôre all going to be okay.

This game has literally no right to be good. But it is! It is incredible. I have now finished it about 5 times on different platforms. This playthrough I sat through and completed the entire game in one single sitting which took me about 3 and a half hours. Honestly one of my favourite games ever made.

So what is the premise of little inferno? Well you burn stuff. It's that simple. Burn everything you get given then buy more stuff to burn. So that sounds boring?! The real fun comes from making combos. Burning the right items together gives you a combo. You get a hint for each of these combos and then you have to work it out yourself.

What really builds this game though is the story. There a few different characters that build together a story throughout the game. They communicate to you only through 1 way, letters. Except somehow the developers seem to find a way to make you relate to these characters and gets them to convey a very wide range of emotion. The story is unique and really keeps you attached throughout the game.

The style of the game is incredible. What I mean by this is the graphics and the soundtrack. They both fit together perfectly. The graphics are cartoon like and everything is stylized incredibly well to fit the theme. The soundtrack is a mixture of tracks that are upbeat and slow and always convey the emotion of the scene. The main theme is great and they even have a nice little sing a long video at the start with a catchy but scary song (you'll know what I mean when you see it). It is definitely something I would be willing to listen to outside of the game.

So theres not really much more I can say about little inferno. The concept of the game is simple and sounds boring and terrible. But somehow it is incredibly fun. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone!

reviewText:
Somewhere uncomfortably wedged in between hilarious and deeply disturbing is this game.

What will you do the first time you light a bus full of school children on fire, hearing their screams before it explodes?

Will you laugh?

Will it shock you?

Will it scare you?

Or will you glare mindlessly into the warm orange abyss, and feel nothing at all?



Is this game about the dangers of over-consumption and runaway-consumerism, leading to a post-apocalyptic society where children are asked to burn their toys in a desperate attempt to stay warm to survive?

Is this game about corporate and government wrongdoing, having milked an entire society dry of all it's resources until the CEOs and top officials flee the planet, leaving the glazed-eyed slack-jawed starving populace to their fate of an eternal nuclear winter?

Is this game a metaphor for the player's wasted life? Like your character who burns all of his toys in the fireplace, is the player burning his life away playing video games, staring into the warm glow of his computer monitor while the real world behind him goes unnoticed, unlived?

Is there any escape offered by burning down your house, the prison that keeps you inside, or is it even worse out there in the unknown?



Playing this game won't give you any answers, but it will let you ask the question.

reviewText:
If Little Inferno was content to be merely a game about sticking a variety of different objects into a fireplace and watching them burn until reduced to ash, it would still be recommendable, as it's full of fun and inventive items to play with. However, the game goes beyond it's surface premise, offering up a critique of its very own genre and a potentially thought provoking story set in an often unsettling and sometimes outright scary world.

As the world gets colder and colder, The Tomorrow Corporation releases the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, which you are a brand new owner of. In order to combat the frigid temperatures outside, you'll spend your days throwing everything from credit cards to televisions to robots (and much, much weirder things) into your fireplace. As you burn, unlocking new items from the 7 different catalogs, you'll interact with others through letters where most of the story is told.

While there are a large amount of items to unlock, and subsequently turn to ash, as well as ‚ÄúCombo‚Äù puzzles to solve, most of the focus of Little Inferno is on the setting and story. A story that, whether by authorial intent or not, is often vague and never very upfront with its intentions. This implicit style of storytelling allows the player to glean however much or little from the game as they want. Is the game really just about burning cool stuff? Or is it using an environmental message as a vessel to tell a deeper metaphorical tale? It's really up to you and how far you want dig into the game.

If that idea turns you off, and $10 seems too steep a price to satiate your inner pyromaniac, this may not be the game for you. For everyone else, whether for its impressive fire effects, its haunting soundtrack, or its intriguing story, Little Inferno is a game likely to stick with you well after you finish it.

reviewText:
From one of the makers of World of Goo comes Little Inferno, a game about setting toys on fire just to watch them burn. As a new recipient of the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, along with Tomorrow Corporation‚Äôs plethora of catalogs, it‚Äôs up to you to stoke the flames. Whether it‚Äôs a pile of blocks or a gaming tablet, a fluffy bunny or a toy school bus, the final destination for all of your things is directly into the fireplace. It is there that they will burn, explode, freeze and rain. And when you‚Äôre all out of things to burn, with the fire slowly reducing your material possessions to ash, you buy some more toys to fuel the fire.

Almost the entire game is spent sitting in front of the fireplace. There are no alternate fireplaces. There are no fireplace expansions. There is no clear objective as to what burning all of your toys is meant to accomplish, aside from staying warm and passing the time. The only actions you have available to you are to upgrade the amount of things you can possess at one time, speed up the delivery of the things you order and unlock new catalogs, each featuring a new set of toys to burn. And, of course, the ability to throw these toys into the fireplace and set them on fire.

But perhaps I‚Äôm getting ahead of myself. This is merely a simple game about throwing things into a fireplace. No need to rush ahead of that. Like how Hydrophobia depicted realistic water collision, Little Inferno approaches its subject with much more consideration than you might expect. The fire, as it spreads from toy to toy, feels real. No two items necessarily burn the same. Toss bricks into the fire and they catch slowly, burn slowly. Toss some of the mail you‚Äôve received and they‚Äôll burn up quick, reduced to cinders in mere seconds.

This doesn‚Äôt take into account the various special items you can burn. Everything from mini-nukes to school buses to replica moons, complete with their own gravity fields, are available to you. There‚Äôs a fan that will blow out the fire. There‚Äôs a fan that will suck in the fire. Toss one on the left side of the fireplace, the other on the right side of the fireplace and you‚Äôve got yourself a funnel of flame, coursing over everything in between. Not happy with how everything turned out? Accidentally froze your fire over? Drop in a mini-nuke and scour it clean with a single blast.

You won‚Äôt have all of these toys available to you at once. In order to access the catalogs you have to do two things. First, you must use all of the toys available to you in the current catalog. It‚Äôs a little forced, but I can see why that‚Äôs a requirement. It‚Äôs in this manner that you‚Äôll know what happens with every toy when they burn. Secondly, you must achieve a certain amount of combos.

A combo in the case of Little Inferno is when you burn two or three like items based on a list of clues. The clues, and the solutions, are relatively simple. The only trick is digging through your growing library of toys to discover which toys are more applicable. Such as, one clue might call for a Sorority Party. Throw in the Low Self-Esteem Action Doll with the Balloons and you‚Äôre one step closer to unlocking the next catalog.

When you purchase an item from the catalog, it doesn‚Äôt immediately appear in your inventory. It takes time. The post office doesn‚Äôt react instantaneously, even in this world. Things may take anywhere from 20 seconds to several minutes to arrive at your doorstep. Don‚Äôt want to wait? Stamps are available to rush delivery, but they are not infinite. There will be times when the only way to proceed is waiting, sitting in front of the fireplace.

Somehow through all of this there is a story. There is a lengthy epilogue that provides a surprisingly satisfactory conclusion to the game. It‚Äôs the kind of ending that encourages you to look back at the few hours you spent in front of the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace. It‚Äôs a strange sort of irony that asks you to question the lack of meaning in something meaningless, but give it time. Think about it some more and you might see how far the metaphor stretches.

And then, when you‚Äôre all done, what‚Äôs there left to do? There‚Äôs not much of a reason to play it after you‚Äôve beaten it. Once you‚Äôve set fire to all of the things, all that‚Äôs left is to fill out the checklist of combos. And once that‚Äôs done, there‚Äôs just the never changing fireplace and your catalogs of toys. They may burn brightly, explode in variable screams, changing the colors of the flames into something truly radiant. Then the flames die out, and there‚Äôs nothing left to do but buy more toys and set them on fire again. And again. And again.

reviewText:
At first glance, Little Inferno seems like a shallow if marginally fun game, but as you progress through the story via the catalogues, the game really opens up. It doesn't have some big epic story, nor does it have one that's consistently at the forefront of the game, in truth much of game relies on abstraction, but that's where the beauty of it lies. The game thrives on abstraction.

The makes several observations that apply very much to both real life events in general, and to gamers and video games in specific. It takes the typical dysoptian/crapsack world and uses it to portray a meaningful message.

The gameplay and graphics are rather utalitarian if charming, it's the story in which the this gem of a game shines, and it's one everyone should hunker down and spend a couple hours on.

reviewText:
This game is two things:

- A fun casual game where you save up money to burn things by, well, burning things. Gameplay is simple, but the results are a lot of fun as each object you burn has a different reaction. You can also find specific combos (hinted at cryptically) that give you extra coins and speed-up tokens, lending the game a puzzle-element.
- An unsettling setting and theme, accompanied by an absolutely amazing score and an ending that had me thinking for several days. This is not something I expected when starting this game, and it took me by surprise, and a delightful one indeed.

I would recommend this game to anybody except perhaps for people that are looking for a challenging experience. Little Inferno offers a wide range of emotions, some not seen nearly enough in videogames, and you owe it to yourself to give it a try.
(...maybe not at full price, but that's a decision I'll leave to you)

reviewText:
Admit it: you like to burn things.  No no, don't deny it, we can all tell it's true.  Fortunately, Little Inferno has your pyromaniac needs covered.

The concept is simple: order things from a catalog with money.  Put those things in a fireplace.  Burn those things.  The act of burning those things earns you more money than you paid for them.  Repeat.  No time limits, no points system, no one telling you OMG DO THIS NOW.  Burn, burn, and burn some more.

That's not to say there's nothing else to the game.  There's combos to create to unlock achievements, along with stamps that help your ordered items arrive faster. Money also lets you purchase access to more items, as well as expand the number of items you can hold at once.  And believe it or not, there IS a plot, given mostly through letters you receive in the mail, along with an epilogue that is a surprising gameplay shift, but still fits in just fine.

You don't have to do any of that though: you're welcome to just burn things without purpose for as long as you like. Doing so is surprisingly entertaining, and really, there are worse reasons to play a game.

reviewText:
Little Inferno is a novelty.  It's a fantastic fire simulation wrapped around some quirky humor and a thin veil of a story, but not much else.

You buy things from a catalog, burn them in your fireplace, and they spit out more money than you spent on the items.  The items have a shipping time which increases over the course of the game, up to about 5 minutes at the end.  You can speed up shipping with stamps which you mostly obtain by burning specific item combos together.

It's a short game, but the novelty wears off even faster.  I really hope these guys go back to a more substantial game like World of Goo again.

reviewText:
You get to burn things in a fireplace.  For money.  And love.

It's a cute tale of the girl next door in a very strange world.  Or something...  I'm really not sure what the story is all about, but it is rather cute.  Essentially you have a pen-pal with your next door neighbor, however you can't go outside and meet her because of the dense smog making it impossible to move.  So instead you order things in the mail to burn in your fireplace to keep warm during the artificial winter.  You burn different combinations of things for different effects, and every so often your pen-pal will write you a letter, sometimes containing a gift.  Which you burn, you monster.

The graphics are very appealing and burning things is always fun.  Even if you don't want to burn stuff, you can always play with the stuff to burn.  Options include various children's toys, one such as building blocks.  If you really wanted to, you could play with those and build yourself a fort.  And then burn it.  There really isn't much left to seek out from what your given.  The game has everything you could want from it.

If you're a pyromaniac, you might as well give it a go.  You won't be let down.

reviewText:
Background: Picked up in a bundle, played with my 8 year old nephew.

Impressions: Enchanting. Absolutely charming and lovingly crafted. I've had few gaming experiences quite as rewarding and intriguing. The simple, talkative exposition via letters is pitch perfect and the holds together perfectly with the gentle score and cute visuals. The story does take some oddly dark turns and some of the visuals are mildly creepy (not for young kids, without being anything bad.. just not all sweetness) which I actually enjoyed as it made the plot all the more interesting.

I can see this is not a game for everyone. It's short, simple and lots of text to read. But if you take the time to enjoy it it's a fine experience.

The Good:
*Simple mechanics, fire looks and works great
*Charming visuals, music and characters
*Each item burns differently.
*Builds a world though letters and descriptive writing
*Dark plot twists and creepy toys add interest
*Combo system is rewarding to puzzle out
*Superb, rewarding and unexpected finale

The Bad:
*Could be longer, all over in a 4-6 hours
*Some combos are really hard to figure out
*The darker elements of the toys and story can be off-putting

Recommended for: anyone with a love of simple, elegant puzzle games with beautifully crafted stories.

Conclusion.
8/10. Not for everyone but there's a lot here if you give it time.

reviewText:
Little Inferno is a toybox game. There aren't any set objectives, there aren't any rules, just pick up your toys, throw them into the fire, and burn them. Ultimately that is the premise to the entire game however there is more to it than that.

You begin with a small number of toys available to order from a catalog, and you can unlock more toys in that catalog by earning money, and you earn money by burning toys. The more toys you burn, the more you can buy, and so on and so forth. You can only 'hold' so many toys in your inventory at one time, however you can increase the size of your inventory by spending some of your money which makes the game a little easier as you progress.

There are numerous other toy catalogs that you can unlock playing the game, but to do so you also have to work out combinations of toys to burn together from combo names which are given to you. Making combinations of burning toys will not only unlock catalogs it will also give you stamps, and these stamps can be used to reduce the time it takes for your toys to arrive once you have ordered them from the catalog - these stamps are invaluable when you get to ordering toys from the very last unlockable catalog as some of the delivery times are around 4 minutes, and this does start to feel like a long time to wait particularly when your toy goes up in a smoke in a number of seconds.

There is a story throughout the game which isn't particularly obvious until right at the very end, and I won't include any spoilers here as I think it needs to be played to be experienced. I found it quite moving, and the whole experience very enjoyable.

This game is fairly short - I managed to complete it in 3 1/2 hours, but I hadn't worked out all of the stamp combos, and I'm actually already keen to go and play it again so I can work the remaining ones out as some combo names are quite cryptic (whereas some are blatantly obvious).

This game is ¬£6.99 on Steam and this is a lot of money for a short game, however I do think if you connect with the gameplay and the story there is scope for replay-ability, and certainly once you've unlocked everything you can just leave it as a 'toy' in itself to pick up and play whenever you fancy burning something on-screen.

Little Inferno is simplistic, it looks great, it's fun, it's challenging, it's polished, it's thought-provoking. I really didn't expect it to be as good as it was. I thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish, and would definitely recommend giving it a try. It's something that can be played in one sitting, or something you can come back to, either way it's definitely something that should be experienced.

reviewText:
Little Inferno looks like a simple, casual game, but it's actually a little deeper than that. Yes, you get to throw stuff into a fireplace. A lot of things, in fact. But way, way into the center of it all there's also a storyline to be found. I won't spoil it so I'll just talk about the gameplay a little bit more. While burning things you'll earn coins and stamps. You see, all items have to be ordered and the stamps will give you the ability to instantly deliver an item to your doorstep. Coins can, of course, be used to buy items or increase the number of objects you can stock.
A few hours into the game these items will dramatically increase in price.

Now, the real goal is to find and create combos. Combining certain items will unlock an achievement and earn you lots of money. And what for ? To buy new items, you got it ! These combos are a must if you want to complete the game, by the way.

Most gamers should be able to finish it in 3,5 hours or so. So it's not all that long, and the time limit for deliveries artificially lengthens the game as well, which is a real shame.

The graphics and animations are cute and beautiful. And the fire looks quite amazing, with all the ashes and whatnot. Impressive stuff if you ask me.

The music is minimal, but memorable. Especially the Weather Balloon song got my attention.
All in all it's a fun game but I wish it was even deeper than this. It's still a bit too shallow for my taste.

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText: Little Inferno is an odd quasi-puzzle game with a similar style and consumerism narrative as World of Goo, 2D Boy's previous acclaimed release. The player is simply tasked with ordering items from a catalog and then burning them in the Little Inferno fireplace. The challenge comes from unlocking more advanced item catalogs, which require a certain amount of burn combinations to access, but you're really here to just be a virtual pyromaniac. Item design is excellent -- I love the screams from the school bus -- and the game's gradually unfolding story (told via snailmail letters) keeps you enthralled to the end. Little Inferno lacks the replayability of World of Goo, but it's an excellent experience on its own.

reviewText:
Well, I'll start with the good points. And probably the best aspect of the game are the graphics, the flame effects in particular. You'd expect that, right? In a game that's all about setting various things on fire that's probably a must. And the game delivers on that, the flame effects are very well done and looking quite realistic. Looking into the fire as it consumes each and every object placed in the fireplace has that mesmerising quality that real fire has. Or at the very least it's quite close.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148662242

Unfortunately that's the only good point for me. After all, it's a game all about setting things on fire. It's fun the first few times, it's fun as you discover new items to burn, but beyond that I found little entertainment in it. There is only one fireplace that doesn't really change through the game, and all the items take time to arrive, completing the simulated mail-order feeling. Sure, there's special stamps that can be used to instantly get the item, but these dwindle fast past the initial boom and getting them later requires completing combos (burn specific sets of items at the same time to get 1-3 stamps) -- a sort of an in-game achievement.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148739036

Contrary to what it seems the game does have a story to it, not a very robust and deep one, but I guess it's enough to serve as background for the pyromaniac frenzy that is the main point of the game. The story advances as more items are burnt and new ones are unlocked and finally reaches an end, offering a short epilogue in the form of a mini point and click adventure.

I can't say I disliked the game, I did enjoy it for a short time, even made myself finish the story. It just doesn't have enough to make me come back. But I suppose it might be a decent choice for a slow chillout evening when anything more than mindless clicking is just too tiring.

reviewText: Little Inferno is an odd quasi-puzzle game with a similar style and consumerism narrative as World of Goo, 2D Boy's previous acclaimed release. The player is simply tasked with ordering items from a catalog and then burning them in the Little Inferno fireplace. The challenge comes from unlocking more advanced item catalogs, which require a certain amount of burn combinations to access, but you're really here to just be a virtual pyromaniac. Item design is excellent -- I love the screams from the school bus -- and the game's gradually unfolding story (told via snailmail letters) keeps you enthralled to the end. Little Inferno lacks the replayability of World of Goo, but it's an excellent experience on its own.

reviewText:
Well, I'll start with the good points. And probably the best aspect of the game are the graphics, the flame effects in particular. You'd expect that, right? In a game that's all about setting various things on fire that's probably a must. And the game delivers on that, the flame effects are very well done and looking quite realistic. Looking into the fire as it consumes each and every object placed in the fireplace has that mesmerising quality that real fire has. Or at the very least it's quite close.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148662242

Unfortunately that's the only good point for me. After all, it's a game all about setting things on fire. It's fun the first few times, it's fun as you discover new items to burn, but beyond that I found little entertainment in it. There is only one fireplace that doesn't really change through the game, and all the items take time to arrive, completing the simulated mail-order feeling. Sure, there's special stamps that can be used to instantly get the item, but these dwindle fast past the initial boom and getting them later requires completing combos (burn specific sets of items at the same time to get 1-3 stamps) -- a sort of an in-game achievement.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148739036

Contrary to what it seems the game does have a story to it, not a very robust and deep one, but I guess it's enough to serve as background for the pyromaniac frenzy that is the main point of the game. The story advances as more items are burnt and new ones are unlocked and finally reaches an end, offering a short epilogue in the form of a mini point and click adventure.

I can't say I disliked the game, I did enjoy it for a short time, even made myself finish the story. It just doesn't have enough to make me come back. But I suppose it might be a decent choice for a slow chillout evening when anything more than mindless clicking is just too tiring.

reviewText:
Little Inferno
A fun yet quite disturbing piece of work. The art style is very incredible and given that there are only two parts to the entire game, (one of which is literally staring into a fireplace) the game is very easy to run on low end devices such as a netbook for example. The aim of the game is to collect combonations of items by burning them together in the fireplace whilst getting the occasional message from one of the three known characters that speak to you:
A love interest with bad typing, a repetitive weatherman and a C.E.O.

There are ninety-nine of these combos and a very evasive one-hundreth.

There are no options to tweek the game to what you wish, not that you need them really in a mobile port. I would have liked to see an audio remover of the sort so that I could play my own music without the light-hearted rumpus in the background. Then again, If I could play the game for six hours in one sitting, nothing much is wrong with said music.


VERDICT:
Is a good time-waster. If you have to download a game, pop on the 'Allow downloads during gameplay' setting and launch this for the time you have to wait. I would see the need to play this for a second time unless perhaps you are showcasing this to freinds or Subscribers. However, should it be the first time you have ever played or seen the game, certainly an eventful 6-7 hrs should you play it in one sitting like myself. Thus, this game receives a ****/***** rating from me. Not five because after all, it's a mobile port.

WARNING: Induces Pyromania, like I am not even joking.



Kind regards,
The Tucker

Little Inferno is a very unique Indie game created by Tomorrow Corperation. The nonsensical, comical game style makes the game highly enjoyable and addictive. The objective of the game is to burn various items in your fireplace in return for coins, with which you buy more items to burn! When you burn certain items together you will unlock combos, these give you extra coins and when you get ebough you are able to purchase a new catalogue containing new items to burn!
When put like that the game does not sound very enjoyable, however the way in which the items react just makes you want to see more of the game.
Tomorrow Corp also add in another couple of characters who you get to meet and develope relationships with as the game progresses including an annoying but lovable neighbour who circums to a tregedy later on in the game.
The game play is very responsive and you do not need a good computer to run the game. The colourful design gives the game a very positive atmosphere, which seems to be uncommon in newer games.
The only down critisism that I have for this game is that it does not take a long time to complete, if you do not focus on unlocking all of the combos you could complete the game in little over 2 hours. But, if you wish to piece together all of the clues than you would have to spend a lot more time on the game.
To conclude:
Little Inferno if a brilliant and unique game, it includes a lot of fun puzzles to solve and will keep someone entertained for a number of hours. It's relaxed game style means you are able to play it without having to stay and finish this bit" as it saves the game as you go.

A small, haunting little game.

The core mechanic is for you to puzzle out unique combinations of items to burn together, based on clues, which then allows you to unlock catalogs containing even more, increasingly strange items to burn.  Rinse, repeat.

Little Inferno took me by surprise.  It's deceptively simple, yet I suddenly found myself with over 2 hours invested into it my first time around.  It went very fast.

I haven't completed the game yet, but I am drawn back to it like a month to a flame.

reviewText:
Little Inferno
A fun yet quite disturbing piece of work. The art style is very incredible and given that there are only two parts to the entire game, (one of which is literally staring into a fireplace) the game is very easy to run on low end devices such as a netbook for example. The aim of the game is to collect combonations of items by burning them together in the fireplace whilst getting the occasional message from one of the three known characters that speak to you:
A love interest with bad typing, a repetitive weatherman and a C.E.O.

There are ninety-nine of these combos and a very evasive one-hundreth.

There are no options to tweek the game to what you wish, not that you need them really in a mobile port. I would have liked to see an audio remover of the sort so that I could play my own music without the light-hearted rumpus in the background. Then again, If I could play the game for six hours in one sitting, nothing much is wrong with said music.


VERDICT:
Is a good time-waster. If you have to download a game, pop on the 'Allow downloads during gameplay' setting and launch this for the time you have to wait. I would see the need to play this for a second time unless perhaps you are showcasing this to freinds or Subscribers. However, should it be the first time you have ever played or seen the game, certainly an eventful 6-7 hrs should you play it in one sitting like myself. Thus, this game receives a ****/***** rating from me. Not five because after all, it's a mobile port.

WARNING: Induces Pyromania, like I am not even joking.



Kind regards,
The Tucker

reviewText:
If Tim Burton made video games, this is probably what he'd make.  It's artsy and metaphorical without being pretentious or obtuse.  The metaphors are pretty plain to see: You burn things to get money you can use to buy things you can then burn for more money... But it has to end sometime.  When shopping, it plays 50's era music to get you in the mindless consumerist mindset, to boot.

Most things don't simply burn.  When you burn sausages from the food catalogue, a swarm of flies bursts out, for example, or an ear of corn pops into popcorn.  This adds a little suspense and entertainment to what would otherwise be just a fireplace simulator.

To give the player something to actually think about, there are unlockable combos" that really do nothing but give you something to complete.  (There are even exactly 100 of them to complete for 100% completion...)  These are mostly puns or "do you remember these items that share a similar theme from 10 minutes ago?"  I.E. "Polar Bear" requires you burn the South Pole and stuffed bear toys together.

That said

It's a simple game, the videos on the store page will give you a good idea of what the gameplay is like - burn things in a fireplace. Hey, hey, kids! How are you doing today? Are you having fun? No? Are you bored of the internet? Cat pictures and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• not enough for you? All these electronics all over the place just white noise getting in the way of your fun? I have an idea!


BURN IT ALL. EVERYTHING. HA HA HA. IT'LL BE TONS OF FUN. AND IT'LL KEEP YOU ALL NICE AND TOASTY-WARM. DO IT. BURN ALL OF YOUR TOYS. BURN IT ALL.


Oh? You can't? Well, why the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• not? It's easy, come on, anyone can do it. Here, I'll even get you started. Here's your own little personal, nonstop, high-definition, entertainment fireplace. Little Inferno! (Uproarious screams of feral children)


Little Inferno is the latest indie masterpiece from the geniuses behind World of Goo, over at Tomorrow Corporation. Originally a launch title for the Wii U's eShop, Little Inferno also found a nice home on PC and Mobile.


Like its predecessor, Little Inferno is incredibly unique. The art style is noticeably distinct, with a strong Tim Burton vibe. And that style seems to leak into every other aspect of the game in all of the best ways. Your only purpose in the game is to burn everything. Burn it all. Let it all burn. If that doesn't sound like fun to you, why, you may as well be at the bottom of the ocean.


Little Inferno will start you off with the meager instruction manual of the fireplace itself, which will burn pretty quick. But everything you burn will fade to dust, and from that dust will pop magical coins. Coins of a material far more valuable than gold, or silver. They're coins of love. Or maybe chocolate, but those would melt close to the fire.


Once you've gotten that far, the entirety of the game opens up to you. You'll be able to purchase a fine selection of perfectly burnable items from one of the many catalogs. Each one brings with it its own unique properties. If you burn batteries, they explode. If you burn wood or paper, it burns very bright and quick. And if you burn living things, why they let out the most delightful scream. But it's not until you've started combining things that the action really starts to heat up. Ba-dum-tss.


Little Inferno is a special game in that it's not one with concrete goals. There are no missions to complete, or collectibles to find. It's a simple game with a simple goal. Burning things. It's not quite a puzzle game, or a physics game, or a sandbox game. But it definitely features elements of all three.

reviewText:
Wow. Just wow.

I originally picked this game up at the recommendation of my mum. She told me to try it because I could burn ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. And sure enough, there is a lot of burning.

In fact, that‚Äôs pretty much all you do. You burn things to earn coins, with which you buy more things to burn to earn more coins. All of which is done in this cute little fireplace you own. Which is apparently marketed toward children. That explains the stunning lack of adult reasoning. Nope. No reasoning here. We burnt it along with everything else.

Of course, there is a little more to it than that. You have to wait for the things you buy to deliver, or use stamps to make them deliver immediately. You earn stamps randomly, or by burning the right things together. And if you royally ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it all up, and you find yourself with no coins and no things to burn, then hang out for a bit. Some bugs will make your fireplace their home, and you can burn them too! And guess what? You get more coins!

At some point you make friends with the person living on the other side of your fireplace. They've got a fireplace too. And they ask you to send them stuff to burn. Because why burn it yourself when you have someone else to do it for you?

There is a rather cute ending to the game. Which oddly enough, did not involve burning stuff. At some point you actually DO stop burning stuff. But I won‚Äôt tell you when. In fact, I can‚Äôt. I burnt the spoiler. Whoops!

In all honesty, this game feels like it was originally developed for mobile devices and ported to the PC later. There are no keyboard controls. Click and drag with the mouse.

The graphics aren‚Äôt bad. The game does lag when you blow things up enough, but I believe that was actually intentional. Add more drama to the explosion, or something like that.

Anyway, I do recommend this game. Even at the $9.99 price tag. It did provide me with a few hours of good entertainment. Most of which were spent waiting for more things to burn, rather than actually burning things.

I will leave you with some sound advice. You get a ticket for a free hug at some point. BURN IT. I wish I did...

reviewText:
Gameplay 1/10:
No failure states, no success states, the gameplay is just the vessel upon which the player's boredom rides to reach the auteurs' conclusion.

Plot 3/10:
Told through letters, and some exposition in the end, it's essentially irrelevant to the experience. One could argue that there are two stories being told: the story of the main character, told via traditional means, and the story of the player, told by the timers on the boxes as they're being stared at by pairs of eyes round the world, eager to discover the next nothing. Finally, there's no closure given, instead the player returns to the start screen, able to pick up from where they left.

Character 5/10:
Ms. Plumps is a classic example of a hamartanousa heroine, who, after being punished, distances herself from the tragic hero, who keeps committing the same crime till the ultimate hubris that will set him free, as it did her. However, none of the characters seems to have any more depth than their cardboard representations: Plumps is the ditz the PC should strive to follow, PC is a blank slate, Weather Man is stuck in his balloon, and Nancy is just someone with a plan that came to fruition regardless of any actions or omission by any other character.

Thought 2/10:
Only there as background noise, seeing as all the characters are single-minded pyromaniacs.

Diction 5/10:
It's what could have saved this game alone, if it was given a little more love. The message is simple, yet powerful. Any gamer has probably felt it (more so any critic/reviewer), however a simple mention of a deep thought is not the same as exploration of the same. In the end it felt like a cheap cop-out.

Melody 6/10:
The music has the decency to not overburden us with its presence.

Spectacle 7/10:
It manages to be pretty throughout; be it through sleek flammable objects, or haunting character design later on.

Final verdict:
Recommended only if you are willing to suffer mild boredom so that you can appreciate its half-baked message.

reviewText: This is just... just one of those things. To literally describe this game, it sounds like abject ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. You get money, you buy things, you burn things, and by burning things, you get money. Where's the hook? Well, there's a very, very subtle storyline, much of which I feel the player has to decide for themselves. A subtle, dark malaise, which hides in the shadows of the gameplay experience. The above description is accurate, all you're going to do is burn stuff over and over, and even if I tell you that different things burn differently and some explode or give random effects, the real hook of this game is that as you do, you're very slowly given hints as to some tragedy in the background. To me, that's almost more compelling than the pure gameplay itself. But, for those who don't give a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, there's plenty to do in finding combos from a list by burning objects together.\n\nIn short, it's cheap, it's quick, it's addictive, and for those who care? It can be a surprisingly deep experience.
